We are experiencing a dual pandemic of COVID-19 and systematic racism. Hopkins Public Schools is facing both public health emergencies head on.

This summer, staff and students of the Hopkins Public Schools District formed an Anti-Racism Task Force. Their mission was to identify where and how systemic racism has been embedded in our district, and to start the conversations and processes necessary to dismantle it. The ultimate goal of the Anti-Racist Task Force is to create a new Anti-Racist District with educators dedicated to creating environments that elevate students and staff of all backgrounds.

This is BIG work and we invite you to be part of it. We will change the way education looks in Hopkins and provide a model for the state of Minnesota and beyond for how things can and should be. We acknowledge as a district and as a community there is still so much work to be done in order to create a more equitable system. We vow to continue this work to create a better future for all our students.

#HopkinsStrong #Vision2031

Hopkins was the second district in not just the state but in the nation to start a Chinese immersion program. The students, staff, and educators were true trailblazers. They went on to develop curriculum and global partnerships, infuse Chinese culture into lessons, and create culturally relevant celebrations.

History matters. Today is Juneteenth – “Freedom Day” for Black Americans. On June 19, 1865 the last enslaved people were freed in the United States, more than two and half years after the Emancipation Proclamation was issued. Minnesota was the fourth state to recognize Juneteenth as a state holiday in 1996. President Barack Obama declared Juneteenth a National Day of Observance in 2014.

Hopkins Public Schools is committed to an equitable education system for all students. There is still work to be done. We are committed to having conversations and making changes that dismantle systemic racism.

Here’s a list of celebrations compiled by KSTP-TV that will take place around the cities in honor of Juneteenth: https://bit.ly/2NebsqY

In the corner of Ellen Dischinger's Glen Lake Elementary School classroom you will find "The Lake," a space meant for self-regulation and calming down.

The Lake includes comfortable seating and a bag of calming tools like stress balls, books, and a Hoberman Sphere. Kindergarteners use the lake when feeling strong emotions, and rejoin the class once they're ready to learn.

Calming spaces like The Lake teach students life-long skills in self-regulation and emotional understanding. As Ellen puts it: "self-regulation has to happen before learning can happen." #Vision2031

On Feb. 5, former Minnesota Supreme Court Justice and NFL legend Alan Page visited Hopkins High School for a student-led panel. The conversation was hosted by Hopkins High School's Invictus Leadership Club, and was the first in a weekly series during February in honor of Black History Month. The series continued today with the the president and CEO of the Urban League Twin Cities, Steven Belton. The final talks will take place on Feb. 18 and 25th with former Mayor of Minneapolis Sharon Sayles Belton and Senator Jeff Hayden.

Hopkins teachers and community members took the stage reading their own prose or choosing to read the work of authors who inspired them. Keenan Jones, Mae Gruss, and Jessica Winnie were among the Hopkins staff who served as readers!
